Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Strategic Science Communication in the COVID-19 Pandemic

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The COVID-19 pandemic is a global crisis threatening millions of lives, the economy, and national infrastructures, including healthcare, housing markets, and industrial supply chains. Health organizations, government, and local communities have introduced various measures to reduce the impact of the pandemic. In this global context, this project examines and compares peopleâ€™s compliance with these measures over time, and across diverse cultural and governance contexts. Specifically, it focuses on how different value and belief systems influence (non-)compliance with containment measures as the pandemic unfolds. In doing so, the research enhances basic understanding of science/policy communications and their impact on public attitudes and behaviors. Ultimately, the project helps identify best science communication practices to inform and educate people about COVID-19 and similar crises.

Policies and scientific recommendations aimed to contain the spread of the COVID-19 virus have generated critical discussions about the prioritization of collective versus individual values. Tradeoffs often focus on public security and health versus individual autonomy and civil liberties. As a result, large-scale societal crises have the potential to shift value prioritization both during and beyond the crisis. By integrating theories from social and cross-cultural psychology, this research explores the role of different value systems, including basic human values, social values, and cultural values, in public responses to the COVID-19 pandemic. A collaborative research network will collect primary data from representative adult samples at three time points during the pandemic. Changes are tracked in public endorsement of different values over the course of three months. Analyses focus on how these changes predict attitudinal and behavioral responses to policies and scientific recommendations. The project also examines the roles of factors such as the severity of the pandemic, socio-economic condition, and existing value systems in these changes. The research will advance scientific understanding of basic human values, how people respond to science communications, and how best to design such communications to achieve important societal goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Coronavirus pandemic is a threat of unprecedented proportions. It spread rapidly and changed many facets of our lives. This project?s aim was to understand both the pandemic?s impacts, and how individuals responded to measures and recommendations intended to prevent further spread of the virus. We tested our research questions in 21 nations, using representative samples in each nation.

We found that people?s tendency to prioritize themselves over their group/nation, was associated with less compliance with scientific recommendations, and less support for further lockdown restrictions. Our results also suggested that people who adhere to social norms more strictly are also more likely to comply with scientific recommendations and support further lockdown restrictions. Building upon these results further, we examined how two nations in particular, the U.S. and China, which differ in the emphasis they place on adherence to norms, would have a shift in their societal and cultural norms. Across the span of only three months, we observed changes that were previously observed over a period of more than 10 years. Specifically, our results suggested that in the U.S., adherence to norms was reduced, while in China it was increased. In turn, these changes influenced trust in and evaluations of the government.

In the same cross-national survey we also found that national identification, namely how much importance a person attributes to their nation for their personal self, also increased compliance to scientific guidelines and support for further lockdown restrictions. In fact, people?s own values also contributed to compliance and support for lockdown restrictions. People who valued safety, security, law and order, and equality, as well as those who endorsed more self-transcendent values, also reported greater compliance and support for lockdown restrictions.

We also studied the politicization of the virus and the extent to which it has polarized responses to the pandemic. In the U.S. specifically, politically conservative individuals adhered to scientific recommendations to a lesser degree than liberals. Our studies expanded upon these findings by showing that not trusting the government, and considering the pandemic to not be a risk, contributes to resistance to comply. In fact, we also found that seeing the pandemic as a challenge rather than a threat generally promoted compliance among liberals, but not among conservatives. Ultimately, our results also suggest that this politicization of responses to the virus are relatively unique to the highly polarized environment of American politics. In other countries, a person?s political ideology either did not relate to, or was even positively associated with, compliance to recommendations, trust in science, and support for lockdown restrictions. Taken together, these findings advance our knowledge of how the COVID-19 pandemic could have influenced people?s psychology, and how people?s psychological makeup impacted their responses to the pandemic. 

Finally, we also explored the effects of the pandemic on various aspects of social life and society in general. For instance, in the U.S., during the early onset of the Coronavirus pandemic, firearm background checks increased at a historically high rate, possibly due to greater uncertainty perceived threat. Second, as the pandemic spread, so did misinformation, causing what has since been termed an ?Infodemic?; utilizing publicly available and nationally representative data of the U.S. adult population, we found that social media consumption during the pandemic increased belief in misinformation about the circumstances of its origin in China, which indirectly influenced attitudes towards Asians negatively. Third, with respect to societal factors that can explain local and national responses to the pandemic during the first six months of the pandemic, we found that nations as well as states within the U.S. that were more peaceful (in terms of lower levels of violence and higher levels of social justice) were better prepared to deal with the pandemic (i.e., had a higher testing rate and a lower positivity rate).
